subject: RE: [junit] Re: Harsh: Selectively running tests
msgSnippet: This is actually what I want to avoid. I have about 100 workbooks and for that I would have to write 100 classes. Unless I misunderstood you. You mention that
messageBody:
This is actually what I want to avoid. I have about 100 workbooks and
for that I would have to write 100 classes. Unless I misunderstood you.
You mention that "A simple script can take the
name of the worbook and run the corresponding test."
How can I write such a script (I assume when you mentioned script, you
mean something outside of the Java ecosystem)?
Harsh.


-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Vijay
Sent: Wednesday, June 14, 2006 1:59 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Harsh: Selectively running tests



Name the test class after the workbook. A simple script can take the
name of the worbook and run the corresponding test.
In JUnit, it is not necessary that the test case class name should be
similar to the name of the class it tests.
Vijay.






[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
